textInput.name: q

item.title: Bethany Nowviskie on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: Bethany Nowviskie
item.description:
Readers may also be interested in Neatline, a newly-released tool for creating timelines and geo-temporal visualizations from the content of Omeka collections:

http://neatline.org/

The timeline feature in Neatline may be used alongside its map-annotation features, or separately (as "Neatline Time"). Users of the larger Neatline plug-in have to ability to indicate ambiguity or uncertainty in events plotted on the timeline, making it a more attractive option for humanities interpretation than most existing timeline systems.

item.title: mauropasi on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: mauropasi
item.description:
Sorry for going around exhuming old questions but there is a new tool that I think is way better than all the others (and I am not just saying that because I work for it).

It's called myHistro and it focuses on the geographical visualization of the events which is something that all other tools lack.

I wrote a short article about its use in the classroom here: http://www.myhistro.com/blog/interactive-timelines-for-teachers-and-students

Mauro Pasi
http://www.myhistro.com

item.title: Wayne Graham on "Open-source historical GIS tools"
item.dc:creator: Wayne Graham
item.description: NYPL's warper is pretty cool. It's an implementation of a Rails-based application called Map Warper (http://warper.geothings.net/) and provides a Ruby wrapper around a cgi program called Mapserver. It's not very evident, but the developer has posted the code on github (https://github.com/timwaters/mapwarper).

item.title: Micah Vandegrift on "Open-source historical GIS tools"
item.dc:creator: Micah Vandegrift
item.description: Not sure if this is exactly what you're looking for but LookBackMaps.net might be worth a shot too. NYPL has done a similar project, not sure what its built on - http://maps.nypl.org/warper/

item.title: Bethany Nowviskie on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: Bethany Nowviskie

item.title: Jason Boyd on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: Jason Boyd
item.description:
Here are some timeline tools & tips I've come across as a part of an environmental scan (I can't vouch for their efficacy):

http://www.timelinemaker.com/
http://www.smartdraw.com/specials/time-line-software.htm?id=137541
http://www.vertex42.com/ExcelArticles/create-a-timeline.html
http://www.ehow.com/how_5065383_make-timeline-template-microsoft-word.html
http://www.templatekit.com/tstore/product_info.php?products_id=256
http://binginfodesign.wordpress.com/2009/02/07/building-a-timeline-template-in-flash/
http://www.squidoo.com/how-to-make-a-timeline
http://www.learningtools.arts.ubc.ca/timeline.htm
http://acl.arts.usyd.edu.au/timelines/
http://www.timetoast.com/
http://www.preceden.com/
http://www.worldhistory.com/

I see Bethany has not mentioned the Temporal Modelling Project: http://iath.virginia.edu/time/

item.title: Patrick Murray-John on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: Patrick Murray-John
item.description: +1 for Brian's SIMILE Exhibit/Timeline material. I've used it a lot, and love the ability to create either very simple or very complex representations of data, especially if you include types and learn to navigate through the relations between data points.

item.title: briancroxall on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: briancroxall
item.description:
I appreciate Bethany's mentioning my timeline tutorial. I need to update it a bit, but if you have any questions while trying to implement a SIMILE timeline, please feel free to shoot me an email or a tweet.

For THATCamp CHNM 2009, I came wanting to talk about time and space, which I wrote about in my pre-camp post. I evaluated a number of timeline tools for this project, and I compiled a spreadsheet about them.

item.title: Bethany Nowviskie on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: Bethany Nowviskie
item.description: And Brian Croxall has a nice tutorial for using Timeline and Exhibit from MIT's SIMILE group, along with Google Docs: http://briancroxall.net/TimelineTutorial/TimelineTutorial.html

item.title: Alex Galarza on "What are some useful tools for creating timelines?"
item.dc:creator: Alex Galarza
item.description:
Still in beta, but CHNM has a handy tool:

http://chnm.gmu.edu/timeline-builder/

item.title: dot.porter on "Open-source historical GIS tools"

item.description: THanks for all the suggestions. I thought I was following this question but didn't receive any updates... so apologies for taking a while to come back to say thank you!

item.title: Bill Ferster on "Open-source historical GIS tools"
item.dc:creator: Bill Ferster
item.description:
Dot,

VisualEyes will do this kind of thing.
It is Flash-based, but you can host the SWF file anywhere:

http://www.viseyes.org
